thread.title: The Wall Street Journal: Dropbox Sets IPO target valuation at $7 billion to $8 billion

title: The Wall Street Journal: Dropbox Sets IPO target valuation at $7 billion to $8 billion

organizations.name: houston  by maureen farrell  dropbox inc.

text:
Published: Mar 12, 2018 9:41 a.m. ET Share 
Web-storage company said it expects its shares to price between $16 and $18 Getty Images Dropbox founder and CEO Drew Houston 
By Maureen Farrell 
Dropbox Inc. set a valuation target between $7 billion and nearly $8 billion ahead of its initial public offering, which is set to be one of the biggest tech IPOs in the past few years. 
In a filing Monday, the web-storage and collaboration said it expects its shares to price in a range of $16 to $18. At the midpoint of that range, based on a fully diluted share count, its valuation would be $7.4 billion, well below the $10 billion valuation where the company had raised private capital in 2014. 
Donâ€™t miss : Dropbox IPO: 5 things to know about the cloud-storage company . 
The Dropbox IPO DBX, +0.00% will seek to raise $612 million of capital at the midpoint of its range, and the company said it would receive proceeds of $529.7 million at that midpoint. 
That valuation level would make it the largest tech IPO since Snap Inc. SNAP, +1.29% made its debut in March of 2017, according to Dealogic. The Wall Street Journal had previously reported the company was seeking a valuation of roughly $7 billion to $8 billion.
